nodes.bodyText: More proper way is to use forkJoin to send the request concurrently (need more code changes and a sample can come from submission related code). I am ok with the current implementation also.
Yes I didn't know how to implement forkJoin for this and I thought that the current approach would be simpler and more straightforward

I am ok with the current implementation also.

I am not; we need to either forkJoin the requests or change the back-end to accept list of course IDs.

I thought that the current approach would be simpler and more straightforward

There is one problem with that argument: you're trading off with accuracy (in some sense).
Okay I'll go see how forkJoin is done in other places and implement it here
You should also bind the [checked] property?

nodes.bodyText: Though I don't like the idea of refreshing page. If you want reload the sessions, just call the corresponding method.
Another question here is why we cannot reuse copySession in the base page?
That copySession requires a SessionsTableRowModel but this page uses a SessionEditFormModel.
Putting this outside of the subscribe function means that this will not wait for the subscription result. This is not exactly what we want because if any of the API calls fail, we need to know.
If there are multiple course IDs, we still need to show toast mentioning that the operation is successful (and if any are failing).

This is not going to work. Subscriptions in Observable are asynchronous, so this line would have been executed before the Observables finish.
Even if this works, this is essentially reloading the page (just less explicit than window.location.reload). Ideally, it should only append the new sessions for the courses that are already pre-fetched.
Appending new sessions to the model doesn't update the view for me so I didn't see any other way than to reload the page. I've pushed my previous implementation (of updating the model).
This is where the actual copying takes place, so this really is not a helper method. It was the previous method that becomes an event handler of some sort.
Use the actual typing instead of any?
Same comments here as the one in instructor home page
This is not going to work. This will almost always return empty list because the list is populated inside the subscribe block, but this method doesn't wait for that.
Do you have any suggestions on how to overcome this problem? The only solution I can think of is busy waiting
Whatever needs to be done afterwards have to be inside the subscribe block.
What do you mean? Return a Observable<FeedbackSession>[] instead of an FeedbackSession[]?
By returning sessionList, you are saying the method is synced (i.e., I can immediately get the copied sessionList), but is it true in the case?
Knowing isAnyFailed is good, but will be better if we know exactly which ones fail. Submission page does that.
How can I retrieve the courseId from the request array?
Take a look at how the submission page does it.

The submission page has the luxury of having the request array creation and forkJoin submission happen within the same method scope, so the catchError block is constructed as part of the request. For me to do something similar here would require extensive code refactoring so this might take some time
You can have this.copyFeedbackSession to construct the error message and just display here. There is no need to know which one is failing here.
The method name doesn't represent what it does. The method returns a list of requests, but the method name implies that it does the copying.

This method (building the requests) should not be concerned with resetting this field. The field needs to be reset when there is a fresh request to copy sessions, not when there is a need to build the HTTP requests.
This is already inside a pipe block, so you shouldn't need to define another .pipe here. Just make the catchError the second argument.
This is not exactly resolving the request; this is merely showing status message.
Similar comment here as copySessionFromRowModel
Single session is just a special case for copying multiple session, is it necessary to have a separate method to handle it?

The flow for single session is completely different because the user gets redirected to edit the session, and since this happens at more than one place I figured having a separate method would be cleaner.
This should not be part of the component, but admittedly I can't really think of a better way to put this that still achieves what we want.
